_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Airgas Specialty Products maintains a comprehensive relase prevention program. The policy mandates ANSI K61.1 Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia. This standard closely resembles the required regulation under OSHA 1910.111. Company policy also requires the implementation of specific engineering and administrative controls to prevent releases as well as a complete Safety & Health Program. Aigras Specialty Prducts does not respond to releases but maintains an Emergency Action Plan that is coordinated with local responders.



Anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia at a concentration greather than 20% are stored and distributed from this location. Ammonia is stored in ASME coded pressure vessels and maintained in totally enclosed systems from railcar to distribution vessels, minimizing transfer losses and accidental release potential.



Airgas Specialty Produts has developed and implemented procedures specific to storage and distribution of anhydrous ammonia to meet the requirements of a prevention program as outlined in the regulation. Process safety information was gathered specific to the process and a process hazard analysis was conducted and operating procedures were written based upon the process safety information and process hazard analysis. Training was developed and provided to all employees. All other elements of the prevention program have been addressed and followed per the PSM and RMP regulations.



Airgas Specialty Products has a written Emergency Action Plan to deal with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia. The plan includes procedures for informing all on-site personnel as well as the required motification of emergency response personnel (local fire departments, state and federal agencies).



This ASP facility has been scrutinized and closely follows the standards and regulations and has continued such at the other ASP locations without major incident for many years, indicating sound processe
s and safety systems, therefore no engineering or administrative controls are scheduled to be implemented toward the improvement of safety.
